ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is a sequel to PLSC 500. If you didn't take 500 it will be very difficult to succeed here. It builds on a great deal of material and the presentation is unorthodox. This is a strength of the course but be prepared to work hard. The material is very challenging and the course is ambitious in scope but you won't find a better course covering the same material at Yale or probably anywhere in the wold. I would recommend it provided Peter is teaching it.

This course is excellent. I would recommend everyone who is doing field research in economics, public health, environmental science to take this course. Causal inference and observational studies have been a huge topic and it is essential for researchers to understand the basic ideas of these topics. Before I took this class I actually don't understand underlying logic of regression and i only know the mathematics part and this course provides a new perspective.

PLSC 503 is a difficult course, with a lot of confusing subject material, but ultimately you will probably do fine. I imagine the course will change dramatically once Peter is no longer teaching it (it will probably become a lot more conventional), so a lot of my advice would probably be unhelpful. But I will definitely say that if you decide to take this course, set aside a lot of time for the psets and readings!
Requires prior knowledge in R but manageable with the TA. Weekly problem sets could be tiring, but definitely worth it for anyone interested in research. Its a great learning experience
Yes, I would certainly recommend the course.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I learn how to think critically about applied research and am cautious about analyzing data from observational studies.
This course was extremely helpful for writing my thesis. I'm already putting what I learned while working as an RA

I've gained the basic literacy in quantitative methods I need to be a critical consumer of political science research, and to begin performing my own replication work. Peter's have been by far the most valuable classes I've taken at Yale.
